<!here> welcome to our AMA with the <https://knotch.com/|Knotch> team! Knotch is a very cool content intelligence platform. We have...
• <@U02Q5J6H7NC> -  <https://www.linkedin.com/in/ellenschwartze/|Sr. Director of Digital Demand Generation>
• <@U01SUSHRUP5> - <https://www.linkedin.com/in/davidbrowncontent/|SVP, Head of Strategy>
...here to answer questions on content strategy. i have quite a few questions, but please feel free to drop questions in the channel. <@U02Q5J6H7NC> and <@U03BMPTTVQU> will reply in the threads (maybe with Loom videos!?). Let's go!

attachments.text: Knotch is the world’s leading Content Intelligence Platform that breaks through the status quo of how businesses connect content to outcomes.
attachments.title: Knotch

text: Hey hey!

elements.text: Hey hey!

text: I’m Ellen, and I’m thrilled to be here! I have been a Superpather for a while now and know there’s tons of great stuff happening in the content space. Can’t wait to hear what questions are on your minds.

elements.text: I’m Ellen, and I’m thrilled to be here! I have been a Superpather for a while now and know there’s tons of great stuff happening in the content space. Can’t wait to hear what questions are on your minds.

text: I’ve dubbed myself the resident Content Nerd at Knotch, hosting our webinars, contributing to blogs (along with the amazing <@U0302RBS7E3>) and love all things content :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I’ve dubbed myself the resident Content Nerd at Knotch, hosting our webinars, contributing to blogs (along with the amazing
) and love all things content

text: Hi everybody, David Brown here.  Strategist by trade, and helping content teams get their strategies in order and connected to business outcomes.

elements.text: Hi everybody, David Brown here.  Strategist by trade, and helping content teams get their strategies in order and connected to business outcomes.

text: our theme today is "Is your content strategy working?" would love a high-level overview of how'd you assess this. content is notoriously tricky to measure. any tips for getting started here would be great

elements.text: our theme today is "Is your content strategy working?" would love a high-level overview of how'd you assess this. content is notoriously tricky to measure. any tips for getting started here would be great

text: <@U03BMPTTVQU> is going to take this one!

elements.text: is going to take this one!

text: how do you balance content at different levels of the funnel, especially when ToFu might bring in more traffic but most senior leaders are interested in higher converting BoFu type content?

elements.text: how do you balance content at different levels of the funnel, especially when ToFu might bring in more traffic but most senior leaders are interested in higher converting BoFu type content?

text: The starting point is to be clear about the objectives you are trying to achieve.  Too often these are not defined, so the question can't be answered about is it working.  When the objectives are defined, these can be translated into KPIs, and you should be collecting performance data to allow you to understand if the strategy is working.

elements.text: The starting point is to be clear about the objectives you are trying to achieve.  Too often these are not defined, so the question can't be answered about is it working.  When the objectives are defined, these can be translated into KPIs, and you should be collecting performance data to allow you to understand if the strategy is working.

text: i think some teams think of demand gen and content as totally separate practices. how do you think about this? how can demand gen and content work better together?

elements.text: i think some teams think of demand gen and content as totally separate practices. how do you think about this? how can demand gen and content work better together?

text: We have seen repeatedly that marketers that do not have clear objectives, KPIs and measurement plans are defunded and cancelled within a year or two.  So it's a race.

elements.text: We have seen repeatedly that marketers that do not have clear objectives, KPIs and measurement plans are defunded and cancelled within a year or two.  So it's a race.

text: <@U02Q5J6H7NC> I can take this one.

elements.text: I can take this one.

text: There's some great academic work on this subject by Byron Sharp that bottom of the funnel efforts is an optimization play, not a growth play.

elements.text: There's some great academic work on this subject by Byron Sharp that bottom of the funnel efforts is an optimization play, not a growth play.

text: I do see this a lot and think it’s a huge missed opportunity. Content and demand gen need to work hand in hand :handshake: ! Each should inform the other. Think of it as a demand gen person: what are you doing if not distributing great content? And from a content perspective, the data a demand gen partner can provide back can be very instructive to what you do next and what is succeeding.

elements.text: I do see this a lot and think it’s a huge missed opportunity. Content and demand gen need to work hand in hand

! Each should inform the other. Think of it as a demand gen person: what are you doing if not distributing great content? And from a content perspective, the data a demand gen partner can provide back can be very instructive to what you do next and what is succeeding.

text: He reports that companies that grow have a consistent and significant effort to grow the top of the funnel to make it broad and deep.

elements.text: He reports that companies that grow have a consistent and significant effort to grow the top of the funnel to make it broad and deep.

elements.text: Without ToFu, there is no BoFu.

text: knotch works with both B2B (e.g. Dropbox) and B2C customers (e.g. Ford). any big differences in content strategy or measurement worth highlighting?

elements.text: knotch works with both B2B (e.g. Dropbox) and B2C customers (e.g. Ford). any big differences in content strategy or measurement worth highlighting?

text: Yes that's the one.  One of the books that we should read annually.

text: Last touch often undervalues the role of content in eventual conversion, first touch gets messy (and ive never seen a company use alone) and not all companies have resources for an MTA model. How do you ensure you're showing the value of content in a last-touch world?

elements.text: Last touch often undervalues the role of content in eventual conversion, first touch gets messy (and ive never seen a company use alone) and not all companies have resources for an MTA model. How do you ensure you're showing the value of content in a last-touch world?

text: I'll take this one.

elements.text: I'll take this one.

text: <@U024BHRFEPQ> We also see in Knotch data how middle-journey content is performing. It’s really easy to miss the middle because it’s not “source” attribution, and it’s not “last-touch” or conversion content. But SO MUCH of your customer journey happens in the discovery/consideration phase. For example, we’ve seen one of our blog posts which has very little to do with our value prop is actually bringing in a lot of traffic, *and then* referring on to more Knotch-specific topics and articles. Without that data, it’d be impossible to know that article’s value.

text: Hey folks! I’m at an early-ish stage startup (<https://butter.us>) where our content strategy is only getting its early legs. We get a lot of positive qualitative feedback so far about our content, but don’t have much definitive data yet (i.e. traffic to our blog is still too low to make any conclusions from). What are some signals that I should be paying attention to in the early days?

text: this post popped up in <#CJ7QQKJ73|-content-strategy-questions> recently: <https://content-career-growth.slack.com/archives/CJ7QQKJ73/p1649752977734379> the gist is that marketing attribution is really hard, so trusting your gut extremely important. curious how knotch thinks about this.

elements.text:
Organic growth, repeat visits, heat map tracking, email subscribers, enquiry forms for lead capture, can all be indicators of successful content marketing. That said, it also depends on the industry you’re in, whether you’re looking at B2B or B2C etc.
This post from Rand Fishkin is great for a different perspective:

attachments.fallback:

This post from Rand Fishkin is great for a different perspective: <https://sparktoro.com/blog/provable-marketing-attribution-is-a-boondoggle-trust-your-gut-instead/>

text: There are major differences in both content strategy and measurement because each of these customers have different objectives.  For example, some are focused on their corporate reputation, and they will want to know that their content efforts are always enhancing reputation not detracting.   Others may be focused on brand consideration, and what to know what content is particular good at this stage of the journey.  Others still may have hard core lead generation goals.

elements.text: There are major differences in both content strategy and measurement because each of these customers have different objectives.  For example, some are focused on their corporate reputation, and they will want to know that their content efforts are always enhancing reputation not detracting.   Others may be focused on brand consideration, and what to know what content is particular good at this stage of the journey.  Others still may have hard core lead generation goals.

text: I’ll elaborate a little based on some of your previous answers above: our acquisition is good, so our objectives right now are really to establish ourselves as a reliable thought leader in the space, gain trust, make people think of us as a resource, etc.

elements.text: I’ve looked into Butter!

text: What we have seen is that marketers are normally excellent at one dimension of the customer journey, and have blind spots about other parts of the journey where content can be really helpful.  For example, post purchase where content can be used to aid product adoption, and to reduce the cost to serve the customer through human channels.

elements.text: What we have seen is that marketers are normally excellent at one dimension of the customer journey, and have blind spots about other parts of the journey where content can be really helpful.  For example, post purchase where content can be used to aid product adoption, and to reduce the cost to serve the customer through human channels.

text: Some metrics I’d look into (I think <@U03BMPTTVQU> should weigh in too!) are more qualitative, since you’re working with low numbers. If your conversion and acquisition is good, look next at time spent on page, and also what we call recirculation rates, aka are your thought leadership posts pushing people to stay on your site to learn more?

elements.text: Some metrics I’d look into (I think

should weigh in too!) are more qualitative, since you’re working with low numbers. If your conversion and acquisition is good, look next at time spent on page, and also what we call recirculation rates, aka are your thought leadership posts pushing people to stay on your site to learn more?

text: <@UUH2ESL66> thanks for the question.  There are two ways to go on this front.  On your brand objectives, you can run brand surveys to content consumers on your website to see if their brand impressions are improving.  Knotch does this well.  The other way to address is to attach yourself to what your sales team is trying to achieve and then report against traffic to product pages or to lead form, or said another way find the bridge that connects content engagement to sales activity, and take credit for what you are driving.

elements.text: thanks for the question.  There are two ways to go on this front.  On your brand objectives, you can run brand surveys to content consumers on your website to see if their brand impressions are improving.  Knotch does this well.  The other way to address is to attach yourself to what your sales team is trying to achieve and then report against traffic to product pages or to lead form, or said another way find the bridge that connects content engagement to sales activity, and take credit for what you are driving.

text:
Hey <@U03BMPTTVQU> <@U02Q5J6H7NC>. What’s your take on John-Henry’s comment here:

<https://twitter.com/JHTScherck/status/1514395167549132803>

Is taking the average CPC of a site’s non-branded keywords, or proposed keywords for a content calendar, a proxy for an organic visit? Like, “how much value will this visit potentially bring to my site?”

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/JHTScherck|@JHTScherck>: Something I've been doing, but am now questioning, is taking the avg CPC of a customer's non-branded keywords, and equating that cost to the value of a single visit in SEO. Useful for building a business case, but the traffic doesn't behave the same & is usually not as valuable.
attachments.text: Something I've been doing, but am now questioning, is taking the avg CPC of a customer's non-branded keywords, and equating that cost to the value of a single visit in SEO. Useful for building a business case, but the traffic doesn't behave the same & is usually not as valuable.

text: Trusting your gut is taking a real risk.  It's worth doing the advanced analytics work to know what behaviors are a pre-cursor of a conversion.  For example in the food category, if you were to follow content that was great at generating social shares, you would not have as much impact as following recipe content that drive lots of "print now" actions.

elements.text: Trusting your gut is taking a real risk.  It's worth doing the advanced analytics work to know what behaviors are a pre-cursor of a conversion.  For example in the food category, if you were to follow content that was great at generating social shares, you would not have as much impact as following recipe content that drive lots of "print now" actions.

text: <@U011QQDDSJV> Tricky one. My take is, consider your target audience. It sounds like he’s honing in on this in the last phrase, “doesn’t behave the same & is usually not as valuable.” If you are bringing in an audience, but it’s not the right one, that’s not worth your time. You risk optimizing for a dolphin when you’re fishing for tuna, ya know?

elements.text: Tricky one. My take is, consider your target audience. It sounds like he’s honing in on this in the last phrase, “doesn’t behave the same & is usually not as valuable.” If you are bringing in an audience, but it’s not the right one, that’s not worth your time. You risk optimizing for a dolphin when you’re fishing for tuna, ya know?

text:
<@U02Q5J6H7NC> - Great tips, thanks!

<@U03BMPTTVQU> - We’re more self-serve SaaS, but we’re definitely tracking conversion rates, etc. Good idea about the brand surveys. We get lots of positive feedback through many channels—I guess I’m just trying to figure out what specific content drives that (or if it’s just a general mix that people like).

Follow up question if you have a second: Any advice for tying content performance to user retention? That’s a bit of a new challenge for me as I come from more of a conversion-focused background :smile:

elements.text: - Great tips, thanks!

- We’re more self-serve SaaS, but we’re definitely tracking conversion rates, etc. Good idea about the brand surveys. We get lots of positive feedback through many channels—I guess I’m just trying to figure out what specific content drives that (or if it’s just a general mix that people like).

Follow up question if you have a second: Any advice for tying content performance to user retention? That’s a bit of a new challenge for me as I come from more of a conversion-focused background

text: :dolphin: ha, yeah, I figured “value” for organic is best determined after the fact…what happened when you published that site, what kind of traffic came in, what journey did that user take, how much did they spent upon conversion. Averages don’t really account for individual user nuance, in my view.

elements.text: ha, yeah, I figured “value” for organic is best determined after the fact…what happened when you published that site, what kind of traffic came in, what journey did that user take, how much did they spent upon conversion. Averages don’t really account for individual user nuance, in my view.

text: i've always liked the term "data-informed" rather than "data-driven"

text: <@UUH2ESL66> it may be easier to check your content taxonomy/tags to see what tags are driving the positivity.  You can ask them directly as well. On user retention, you could look at your email nurture programs for clients, and track users who are both retaining or lapsing, and see how their email click throughs vary.  This may also give you an indication of who is at risk of lapsing so you work to save them before the lapse occurs.

elements.text: it may be easier to check your content taxonomy/tags to see what tags are driving the positivity.  You can ask them directly as well. On user retention, you could look at your email nurture programs for clients, and track users who are both retaining or lapsing, and see how their email click throughs vary.  This may also give you an indication of who is at risk of lapsing so you work to save them before the lapse occurs.

text: Makes a ton of sense! We’re just about to dive into our nurture campaigns again so this will be great to keep in mind.

elements.text: Makes a ton of sense! We’re just about to dive into our nurture campaigns again so this will be great to keep in mind.

text: What I’ve done in the past (the time i refer to as “Before Knotch”) I would look at traffic, and if possible, layer sentiment on. There’s also a lot of collation of data you could do; aka was it popular on LinkedIn? If you work with sellers, did they get more feedback or better responses? I once make an executive briefing that booked 6 meetings off of 12 emails… :boom: … but that data would never have shown up in a web portal stat. I also would warn to think critically of a high-traffic piece if you *don’t* have that sentiment layer, especially if your brand has recently had a stroke of bad news. If you’re getting traffic that poorly affects the brand, back away quickly.

elements.text: What I’ve done in the past (the time i refer to as “Before Knotch”) I would look at traffic, and if possible, layer sentiment on. There’s also a lot of collation of data you could do; aka was it popular on LinkedIn? If you work with sellers, did they get more feedback or better responses? text: <@UJG9WTEKG> <@U037SSZSU3W> It depends on your overall strategy and the business goal you are trying to drive with content.  If your remit is brand building, then looking at a combination of page views and engagement will give you directional information.  If you can, you can also use survey questions at the asset level (part of what knotch offers) to understand if the content is providing value to the audience.  If your remit is driving lower funnel actions (downloads, demo request etc.) then looking at what content can be attributed to those actions. This is also something Knotch focuses on, looking at content attribution across first, last and MIDDLE touch.  At the end of the day you want to identify what content is influencing action

elements.text: It depends on your overall strategy and the business goal you are trying to drive with content.  If your remit is brand building, then looking at a combination of page views and engagement will give you directional information.  If you can, you can also use survey questions at the asset level (part of what knotch offers) to understand if the content is providing value to the audience.  If your remit is driving lower funnel actions (downloads, demo request etc.) then looking at what content can be attributed to those actions. This is also something Knotch focuses on, looking at content attribution across first, last and MIDDLE touch.  At the end of the day you want to identify what content is influencing action

text: Now that I have access to Knotch, it’s all presented in a platform and what I look for is positive sentiment, scroll depth WITH good time on page, and — if the page has a high-value CTA (book a demo, register, etc), is that a good ratio with the traffic it’s getting?

text: i'm curious what you've learned about content attribution by building a product in the space?

elements.text: i'm curious what you've learned about content attribution by building a product in the space?

text: Building on Andrew's thoughts, you can create two tables of your URLs - one ranked by page views, the other ranked high value actions, and then calculate the conversion rate.  For high conversion rate pages with low views, you need to grow traffic to those pages.  For high traffic pages but low conversion rate, you need to find a way to improve conversion.  Approach this decile by decile.

elements.text: Building on Andrew's thoughts, you can create two tables of your URLs - one ranked by page views, the other ranked high value actions, and then calculate the conversion rate.  For high conversion rate pages with low views, you need to grow traffic to those pages.  For high traffic pages but low conversion rate, you need to find a way to improve conversion.  Approach this decile by decile.

text: how much do you take into account "building topical authority for money pages" in your content strategy? for example, you want a product or category page to rank higher, so you create supporting blog content that links back to those pages (B2C here obvi)

text: for example, we found that for Fintech companies, it takes an average of 10 content assets over 14 DAYS to get an audience to convert. If that audience has never heard of the brand, make that 24 DAYS and 16 content assets

text: This is Knotch's arena.  We organize content performance around 4 pillars - enhance brand, grow  audience, improve ROI and lastly understand the content journey.  Rather than include metrics, you should focus on KPIs.  All KPIs are metrics, but not all metrics are KPIs

text: Unfortunately not, it varies tremendously from brand to brand and depends on the length of the journey, how they got to the page from a referral perspective etc. Its literally why we built Knotch because getting that data out of GA/Adobe is impossible

text: Gotchya. It’s a balance, in my experience. You can’t write only for the bots; people ultimately sniff it out. This is where the middle attribution would be able to unveil what is really working for the audience when they land on that piece. Ultimately, it needs to resonate so well with the consumer, not the bot, that it’ll be stuck in the back of their mind so the next time they need detergent they think of natural alternatives, and think of your brand as one that cares about that topic.

elements.text: Gotchya. It’s a balance, in my experience. You can’t write only for the bots; people ultimately sniff it out. This is where the middle attribution would be able to unveil what is really working for the audience when they land on that piece. text: IMHO, my leadership has wanted content, and marketing in general, to try to map to what’s truly driving $$ (whether sales of detergent or SaaS). If your page is resonating with bots _*which in turn*_ boosts readership _*and then*_ sales, that last step is the step you’d want to prove.

elements.text: IMHO, my leadership has wanted content, and marketing in general, to try to map to what’s truly driving $$ (whether sales of detergent or SaaS). If your page is resonating with bots
which in turn
boosts readership
and then
sales, that last step is the step you’d want to prove.

text: Thank you, <@UJG9WTEKG> and Superpathers! If you’re skimming this after we’re “live” - please still feel free to tag me with a Q, and I’ll coordinate an answer for you.

elements.text: Thank you,
and Superpathers! If you’re skimming this after we’re “live” - please still feel free to tag me with a Q, and I’ll coordinate an answer for you.

text: Thank you Ellen! I guess I’m asking broadly. Working at an agency, we get a lot of questions about this from customers so I’m curious to hear how others think about this!

elements.text: Thank you Ellen! I guess I’m asking broadly. Working at an agency, we get a lot of questions about this from customers so I’m curious to hear how others think about this!

text: Good luck with your pivot Ellen! And your hype coworking space (sounds fun!)

elements.text: Good luck with your pivot Ellen! And your hype coworking space (sounds fun!)

text: Lots of you were asking about which metrics, and I had to make sure to drop the Knotch dashboard (our content director lives in it!) here. We’ve uncovered a lot of our own insights already :slightly_smiling_face: . What brands are seeing tons of value in specifically is that you can see which piece of content OR source is driving value, plus the total time to conversion for that particular journey/source. It’s very instructive for us.

elements.text: Lots of you were asking about which metrics, and I had to make sure to drop the Knotch dashboard (our content director lives in it!) here. We’ve uncovered a lot of our own insights already

. What brands are seeing tons of value in specifically is that you can see which piece of content OR source is driving value, plus the total time to conversion for that particular journey/source. It’s very instructive for us.

text: (Note this is demo data for public consumption :wink: )

elements.text: (Note this is demo data for public consumption

text:
So, we’re working on defining our ‘leading indicators’ — what exactly are we going to look for as early signals that the engine is about to turn over. For example, in 30 days we might look at
• have we brought in net-new people within out new persona? 
• are those people actively engaging with us (on any medium)
• Have we seen an uptick in traffic in conjunction with our events or other activities?

elements.text: So, we’re working on defining our ‘leading indicators’ — what exactly are we going to look for as early signals that the engine is about to turn over. For example, in 30 days we might look at
have we brought in net-new people within out new persona?
are those people actively engaging with us (on any medium)
Have we seen an uptick in traffic in conjunction with our events or other activities?

text: It’ll be different from place to place, that’s why it’s important to understand your buyer’s typical cycle. Are you able to speed that up?

elements.text: It’ll be different from place to place, that’s why it’s important to understand your buyer’s typical cycle. Are you able to speed that up?

text:
Yes makes sense.

One strategy I’m working on is b2c at a $2.5k price point. We think it’s a 3-6 month sales cycle but we’re trying to speed it up to 30 days with a free trial and a content driven onboarding experience during that trial. We’re in an experimenting mode though and changing things rapidly…what we’re trying to do currently is break leads out into weekly cohorts so that we can rapidly iterate over 6-8 weeks.

Up to this point, we’ve tried a lot of different things but changed too quickly to get enough data to measure the success of our experiment / how we can improve, which is another reason I was curious.

elements.text:

One strategy I’m working on is b2c at a $2.5k price point. We think it’s a 3-6 month sales cycle but we’re trying to speed it up to 30 days with a free trial and a content driven onboarding experience during that trial. We’re in an experimenting mode though and changing things rapidly…what we’re trying to do currently is break leads out into weekly cohorts so that we can rapidly iterate over 6-8 weeks.

Up to this point, we’ve tried a lot of different things but changed too quickly to get enough data to measure the success of our experiment / how we can improve, which is another reason I was curious.
